paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b, an Earth-sized rocky planet orbiting an M dwarf, retain any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed TRAPPIST-1 b system
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Phase-resolved thermal spectra from JWST MIRI
datasets_or_cohorts.description: One rocky exoplanet (TRAPPIST-1 b) with phase-resolved thermal spectra obtained through JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Null scenario (bare-rock)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution used as the null hypothesis for comparison against atmosphere-bearing scenarios.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption, particularly featuring CO2 spectral signatures around the 15 um band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Oxidized composition atmosphere model with weaker CO2 signature constraints, serving as an alternative atmospheric composition hypothesis.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions including circulation models, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features in the data.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
